displayed_text: Patient: I’ve taken medicine. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m like eh. Doctor: So, really what I’m hearing here is that you’ll let me give you the blood. Healthcare Professional: Well uh, let’s see when Patient: Yeah, I can call in. I can call in. Doctor: Nobody leaves. Healthcare Professional: Let’s try it. Doctor: And then we’ll see about Dr. S_____. Nobody leaves. Nobody leaves. Patient: She said nobody leaves so I’m gonna sit here. Doctor: Nobody leave.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct. Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that is not immediately making us have to worry from a treatment standpoint. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of you, if I want to get better control of this situation – Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: - it’s better that we start thinking about doing this medicine. Patient: Mm, hmm. So what else, what is the other um other than the weakness, the tiredness? Doctor: The other one is we monitor your liver numbers and we do that by blood tests. You know I always check your blood when you come in. Patient: Man… Doctor: We check out your liver and make sure it’s tolerating it. Patient: They’re taking ten or twelve tubes doc every time I get there but I got a good vampire. Doctor: You do, you do have a good vampire. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

Patient: No. Doctor: You get them? Patient: Typically not. Actually, I never have. Doctor: You want one? Patient: Um, going into this, hearing from other patients, they say it’s advisable. I’ve heard, I don’t know. I, uh Doctor: I’m a big fan. Patient: Then, I guess I will. Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the

Patient: Ahhhh I leave this Wednesday and I come back on the fifteenth of February. That is negotiable. Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I need to hop a plane and come back here… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …that is not a problem. Doctor: And you have been off the Casodex now for a couple weeks? Patient: By whenever yeah, Doctor: Something like that, okay. Patient: two weeks ago today. Doctor: Yeah, okay. Let me give you the brief summary of what I think is happening because I know you like it itemized so we have a plan. One, your PSA’s going up but not unexpected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because we talked about how Provenge just doesn’t touch that PSA.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: so no out-of-pocket for us? Doctor: Of gosh no that that you cannot get outside of the clinical trial. Patient: Really. Doctor: So you can’t get it if you tried. (Laughs) Patient: It’s so new. Uh and uh do you think within a month or two months we’ll know if it’s working? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah so I’m hoping to get you started within the next two or three weeks. Family Member: Oh yeah I mean we want to start right away. Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey.

Patient: I think, I think you answered all my questions pretty good. Huh, the only thing, the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: When would that start? Doctor: Huh, so, it, that would start if you are doing the clinical trial, then once you sign the paper, you could start a couple of days after that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so it’s not going to delay getting that started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Huh, we might make the decision when you’re back in a month, huh, and then we can go from there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you need a refill on your morphine? Or are you good? Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And kind of try to, and then I’m going to find out probably today or tomorrow what this color test --- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I don’t get anything from this test. It’s just an easy one to do. Family Member: Yeah, you know what MTHFR is? Do you know is that related to this? Because our daughter has that. Doctor: I don’t know what that means. Family Member: She also has an autoimmune disease. Doctor: What is MTHFR? Family Member: That’s some genetic thing, right? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Our youngest daughter. Patient: That was discovered and looked at by a guy named A_

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: You had to scare me like that. I have no idea. Family Member: I just gave him some M and M’s. Good thing I brought them in. Not M and M’s but Good and Plenty. Doctor: Why you running so low? Family Member: He ate breakfast but he didn’t eat it all at the restaurant. Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: He had an omelet and toast and .

Patient: Ooooh I wanted to go to the F___. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re having, my church is having a bike blessing on the twenty fourth. Doctor: Of? Patient: Of this month. Doctor: Oh, okay, fine. Patient: And so I wanted to leave… Doctor: Well if you go do that, - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: if you go do that, When do you come back? Patient: I don’t know doc. It might feel good to me. Doctor: That’s nice but you got to come back. So when are you coming back?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm. Patient: Yeah Lupron continues regardless of any of the options? Doctor: No matter what that continues and then we add other things on top. Patient: Even with the PARP inhibitor or the chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Lupron goes with the chemo? Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: I don’t know how you miss all that. Doctor: It would look like the needle would hit more. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Do you want this. There’s the picture over here. Those are the slices. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Those are the seminal vessels. (Pause 10 seconds) Family Member: And this, we were just surprised because there’s nothing that would indicate all that. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: His PSA being low, and the prostate not being enlarged, and the preliminary report they told us we thought when you called down that day we were here. Doctor: I know. I’m really upset by passing incorrect information to you based on the verbal report. That’s the danger of doing that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. I’m like what were you looking at? The other sixteen lymph nodes first? (Laughs)

Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah- Doctor: Huh? Patient: Can you get somebody to send me like five thousand dollars? Doctor: To what? Doctor: Hum, but, then, you guys tell us, but we should make a decision one way or the other. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m going to give you those side effect sheets. Family Member: Yes. Please. Doctor: We’ll start there. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember? Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream –
